title: [FG-VD-19-009] Intel(R) Trace Analyzer and Collector 2019 Memory Corruption Vulnerability Notification
vulnerability_information:
The Vulnerability Report along with PoC file has been shared in the PGP encrypted [using Intel Public Key] Attachment along with this report.

## Impact

Memory Corruption & Arbitrary Code Execution.
vulnerability_information_html:
The Vulnerability Report along with PoC file has been shared in the PGP encrypted [using Intel Public Key] Attachment along with this report.

Impact

Memory Corruption & Arbitrary Code Execution.

activities.message:
Hello Intel Product Security Team, 

Good Morning.

Firstly, I would like to thank you for responding so quickly, I sincerely appreciate it.

Secondly, this report is completely different from #483573 and I would like to kindly request you to first view the reports first and thereafter mark them as duplicate after some insight. 

The target binary is different, PoC is different, Crashing location is different. Due to all these differences, our Internal Vulnerability ID is also different as clearly seen in the Hackerone Report Title.

Therefore, I would like to kindly request you to remove the Duplicate status and actually view the PGP Encrypted Vulnerability Reports.

Eagerly awaiting your response.

Thanking You,

Yours Sincerely,
Kushal Arvind Shah.
Senior Security Researcher | Fortinet's FortiGuard Labs.

activities.message:
Kurshal,
 
Our product team has been unable to reproduce the issue you've reported. 3 independent attempts failed on Windows 10 and Window 7 SP1 64-bit with the same result (below). Is there any additional information or steps you can provide (PGP encrypted) that will enable us to reproduce this issue?

Cannot be read  PoC.STF
Check name, permissions, whether this is really a trace file and the trace is valid
Also check that all parts of the trace file, if they exist, are located in the same directory 

Best Regards,
Intel Product Security Incident Response Team
www.intel.com/security 
secure@intel.com

Also check that all parts of the trace file, if they exist, are located in the same directory

Best Regards,
Intel Product Security Incident Response Team

secure@intel.com

activities.message:
Hello Intel Product Security Team, 

Good Afternoon.

Firstly, I would like to thank you for responding so quickly, I sincerely appreciate it.

Secondly, I am able to consistently reproduce the Vulnerability on my patched Windows 7 SP1 64-bit machine. The instructions to reproduce the Vulnerability are mentioned in the original report and I am sending them again [PGP encrypted] for your perusal/referral.

I would recommend using the latest WinDbg debugger, even though older versions work too.

Similar to the Reproduction Steps mentioned in the original report, I am re-sending some Step-By-Step Reproduction Steps (PGP Encrypted) for this Vulnerability.

In the case, you are still unable to reproduce the issue, I can share a Video Recording of the same.

Eagerly awaiting your response.

Thanking You,

Yours Sincerely,
Kushal Arvind Shah.
Senior Security Researcher | Fortinet's FortiGuard Labs.

activities.message:
Kushal,

We are pleased to inform you that the issue you’ve reported is eligible for bounty. The CVSS Base Score: has come out as a low 3.3.  Intel PSIRT will contact you as soon as we have more details on mitigation and disclosure timeline.
 
Best Regards,

Intel Product Security Incident Response Team
www.intel.com/security 
secure@intel.com

activities.message:
Kushal,

The CVSS Base Score has come out as a low 3.3.

https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:H/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N

Please continue to abide by the coordinated disclosure embargo through the coordinated public disclosure date.
The current target date for public disclosure is June 11th 2019. 
Let me know if you have questions or concerns. 

Best Regards,

Intel Product Security Incident Response Team
www.intel.com/security 
secure@intel.com

activities.message:
Hello Intel Product Security Team,

Good Afternoon.

Firstly, I would like to thank you for responding, I sincerely appreciate it.

Secondly, I disagree with the CVSS V3 Base Score of 3.3 because of the following:-

1) Availability should be High and cannot be None, since there is a clear and always reproducible crash (DoS) of the vulnerable software.

2) Integrity should be High and not Low, because this is a clear Out of Bounds "Write" issue allowing an attacker to modify resources.

3) The attack complexity should be Low and cannot be High, since all an attacker needs to do is send a trace file to the victim for processing.

4) Privileges Required should be None and not Low, since the attacker does not need any privileges to send the malicious trace file to the victim for processing.

Thereby the correct CVSS score is 7.3 and the vector string for the same is https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:H/A:H

Therefore, I would like to kindly request you to re-review the aforementioned CVSS vector string and the reasons mentioned above.

Also I will be abiding by the coordinated public disclosure date of June 11th 2019 and we will be publishing our Advisory for this issue on June 12th 2019, by which date this Vulnerability should most likely be patched by Intel Corporation.

Also I would like to request you to share the CVE-ID for this Vulnerability and to credit us using the text "Kushal Arvind Shah of Fortinet's FortiGuard Labs".

Eagerly awaiting your response.

Thanking You,

Yours Sincerely,
Kushal Arvind Shah.
Senior Security Researcher | Fortinet's FortiGuard Labs.

activities.message:
Kushal,

We have reviewed the provided information and compared it with the CVSS definitions on first.org.  Upon retaking, this is a 4.2 Medium.  Below is the updated string:

https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:H/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L

1) Availability for DoS is 'low' since it is not a permanent denial of service.

2) Integrity is a 'low' since this is not a total loss of integrity or complete loss of protection.

3) Attack Complexity is 'high' since the attacker needs someone else on the system (authenticated user) to run the file.  The attacker cannot do this themselves.

4) Privileges Required are 'low' since only an authenticated user can execute.

Best Regards,
Intel Product Security Incident Response Team

1) Availability for DoS is 'low' since it is not a permanent denial of service.

2) Integrity is a 'low' since this is not a total loss of integrity or complete loss of protection.

3) Attack Complexity is 'high' since the attacker needs someone else on the system (authenticated user) to run the file. The attacker cannot do this themselves.

4) Privileges Required are 'low' since only an authenticated user can execute.

Best Regards,
Intel Product Security Incident Response Team

activities.message:
Kushal,

I apologize for the delay in responding to your last note. We have concluded our analysis of the two issues you reported. Both stem from the same weakness in the application which may cause a non-persistent crash.  However, we do not feel that this would be classified as a security vulnerability and, normally, would not be eligible for a reward.  

Regardless of the classification, this was a valuable report and the weakness will be fixed by our product team in a future release.  To show our appreciation, we would like to offer you a reward of $1,500.  

This reward is outside of the normal criteria for our Bug Bounty program, which is focused on rewarding valid security vulnerabilities in Intel products, and should be considered an exception.  

Please let me know if you have any questions or if you would like to have a call to discuss this further. 

Best Regards,

Alan Mc Ninch
Intel Product Security Incident Response Team
www.intel.com/security 
secure@intel.com

activities.message:
Hello Alan Mc Ninch, Intel Product Security Team,

Good Evening.

Firstly, I would like to thank you for responding, I sincerely appreciate it.

Secondly, I would like to request for a response to the following:-

1) The severity was recently updated from from Medium to None for a CVSS 3.0 score of 4.2 Medium Memory Corruption Vulnerability in a commercial /paid Intel Product. How could a Memory Corruption Vulnerability in an Intel Product priced at $2949 with a valid Vulnerability have a severity set as None?

2) You mentioned that "This reward is outside of the normal criteria for our Bug Bounty program, which is focused on rewarding valid security vulnerabilities in Intel products, and should be considered an exception." BUT, I noticed a similar Vulnerability (Heap Overflow local vector) in the Same Product reported by another Hackerone Researcher and Acknowledged by Intel Security Team in 2018. The link to the Intel Security Advisory is https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/security-center/advisory/intel-sa-00180.html, bearing CVE ID CVE-2018-12174 and the respective Researcher was https://hackerone.com/jplopezy. Could you please explain 

3) I have several more Vulnerabilities in Intel VTune Amplifier, Intel Trace Analyzer, Intel System Studio, Intel Parallel Studio, Intel OpenVINO toolkit, Intel Quartus Prime, Intel Media Server Studio and several other Intel Paid Products. Are they also Out-Of-Scope for the Intel Bug Bounty Program? 

4) Both this report #483572 and  #483573 are different since the Binaries in question are different, the PoCs are different, the crash location is different. One report is for the "Intel Trace Collector Application" and the other is for the "Intel Trace Analyzer Application". Could you share the root cause as to how report #483573 was closed as Duplicate of this report. 

I am attaching both the 2018 Intel Advisory for this "Same product" and the Hackerone Researcher's profile page who reported that other Vulnerability to Intel Security Team along with this comment.

It is extremely disheartening to see Intel first downplay the Severity in the CVSS scoring, thereafter merge two distinctly different issues into one and thereafter say that the Vulnerability is out of normal scope and an exception is being made when clearly a similar vulnerability in the same product has been fixed and acknowledged by Intel just 3 months ago. 

I hope some clarity can be brought into this matter, so that I can responsibly report the other findings I have found "if they are in scope of this program without any exceptions".

Eagerly awaiting your response.

Thanking You,

Yours Sincerely,
Kushal Arvind Shah.
Senior Security Researcher | Fortinet's FortiGuard Labs.

activities.message:
Kushal,

Each bug bounty report is individually evaluated for applicability and inclusion in the program based on the technical details.  Not every reported issue is accepted and no two issues are identical.  Eligibility for any award, and award determinations are made at Intel’s sole discretion as defined in the Intel bug bounty terms:

https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/security-center/bug-bounty-program.html

Best Regards,

Alan Mc Ninch
Intel Product Security Incident Response Team
www.intel.com/security 
secure@intel.com
